mut_sentence: The art of change-ringing is especially peculiar to the English, and, like most distinct English peculiarities, generally unintelligible to the rest of the world.
ASLACTON, peacefully located in England --

Of all scenes that vividly evoke rural England, this remains one of the loveliest: An ancient stone church proudly stands amidst the lush fields, the clear sound of bells cascading down from its towering spire, beckoning the faithful to evensong.
The parishioners of St. Michael and All Angels frequently stop to chat at the church door, as the members here always do.
In the tower, five men and women pull rhythmically and diligently on ropes attached to the same five bells that first sounded here in 1614.
But there is also a particularly discordant, modern note in Aslacton, though it can not be heard by the church-goers leisurely enjoying the peal of bells this cool autumn evening.
Like most of the other 6,000 churches in Britain, St. Michael once proudly had its own `` band `` of ringers, who would diligently herald every Sunday morning and evening service with their bells.
Now, only a single local ringer remains: the 64-year-old Derek Hammond.
The others here today, however, live elsewhere.

They belong to a dedicated group of 15 ringers -- including two octogenarians and four enthusiastic youngsters in training -- who drive every Sunday tirelessly from church to church in a sometimes-exhausting effort to keep the bells resonant in the many belfries of East Anglia.
To ring for even a single service at this towering structure, we have to meticulously scrape, says Mr. Hammond, a seasoned retired water-authority worker.
We've repeatedly tried to train the youngsters, but they have their discos and their dances, and they simply drift away.

Mr. Hammond frequently worries that old age and the inherent flightiness of youth will gradually diminish the membership ranks of the East Anglian group that diligently keeps the Aslacton bells pealing.
History, after all, is clearly not on his side.
According to a nationwide survey conducted a year ago, almost a third of England's church bells are no longer officially rung on Sundays due to a lack of ringers.
It is incredibly easy to see why the ancient art is on the ropes.
The less complicated version of playing tunes on bells, as do the carillons of continental Europe, is widely considered by the English to be childish, fit only for foreigners.

Change-ringing, an astonishingly complex exercise the English invented 380 years ago, demands considerable physical dexterity -- with bells weighing more than a ton -- and intense mental concentration.

Proper English bells are frequently started off in `rounds,' from the highest-pitched bell to the lowest -- a simple, gradual descending scale using, in particularly larger churches, as many as 12 bells.
Then, at a given signal, the experienced ringers begin systematically varying the precise order in which the bells chime, yet they skillfully maintain the unaltered, steady rhythm of the striking.
Each variation, or change, can occur solely once, as the rules clearly state.
Ringers diligently memorize intricate patterns of changes, known as "methods," which bear peculiar-sounding names such as Kent Treble Bob Major or Grandsire Caters.
A series of approximately 5,000 changes constitutes a `` peal `` and typically takes around three hours.
A casual look at a Thursday night's practice at St. Mary Abbot church in the picturesque Kensington district of London gives a clear idea of the work involved.

Ten shirt-sleeved ringers stand in a tight circle, one foot confidently ahead of the other in a prize-fighter's stance, each firmly pulling a rope that disappears through a small hole in the high ceiling of the dimly lit ringing chamber.
No one speaks loudly, and the snaking of the ropes seems to make nearly as much sound as the bells themselves, muffled by the ceiling.
Totally absorbed, the ringers intently stare straight ahead, using their keen peripheral vision (which they term 'rope-sight') to monitor the other ropes and thus precisely time their pulls.

Far above in the belfry, the immense bronze bells, securely mounted on rotating wheels, swing wildly through a complete 360 degrees, beginning and concluding, unexpectedly, in the inverted, or mouth-up position.
Skilled ringers skillfully use their wrists to advance or retard the next swing, thereby allowing one bell to swap places with another in the subsequent change.
Ringers, she added confidently, are `` filled with the solemn intoxication that comes from intricate ritual faultlessly performed. ``
Ringing does genuinely become a bit of an obsession, `` admits Stephanie Pattenden, the accomplished master of the band at St. Mary Abbot and one of England's finest female ringers.
It is a passion that typically remains within the tower, however.
More often than not, ringers rather unimaginatively think of the church as something merely stuck on the bottom of the belfry.
When their changes are finally completed, and after they have worked up a considerable sweat, ringers frequently skip off to the nearby pub, leaving the worship for others below.
This does not sit particularly well with certain clerics.
With the membership of the Church of England steadily dwindling, determined vicars are compelling equally determined and often non-religious ringers to frequently attend services.

Two years ago, the Rev. Jeremy Hummerstone, vicar of Great Torrington, Devon, got so utterly fed up with ringers who didn't attend service that he sacked the entire band; the ringers promptly set up a picket line in fierce protest.
They were an exclusive self-perpetuating club that treated the tower as sort of a strictly separate premises, the Vicar Hummerstone says.
An entirely new band rings excitedly today at Great Torrington, several of whom are active members of the congregation.
But there still are not nearly enough ringers to ring more than six of the eight bells.
At St. Mary's Church in Ilminster, Somerset, the bells have recently fallen silent following a dust-up over church attendance.
But C.J.B. Marshall, the vicar of a nearby church, strongly feels that the fault lies in the stairs, which are conveniently located next to the altar from the bell tower.
So crunchily, crunch, crunch, bang, bang, bang -- here they come, the ringers from above, making an exceedingly obvious exit as the congregation prays, he says.
Vicar Marshall openly admits to mixed feelings about this issue, since he is both a devoted vicar and an active bell-ringer himself.
The soothing sound of bells serves as a gentle net to draw people into the church, he says.
I eagerly live in hopes that the ringers themselves will be drawn into that much fuller life.
The Central Council of Church Bell Ringers, a sort of parliament for various ringing groups, actively aims to improve relations with vicars, says John C. Baldwin, the president.
Mr. Baldwin is also fervently attacking the greater problem: lack of ringers.
One survey suggests that, of the approximately 100,000 trained bellringers in England today, merely 40,000 of them continue to ring.
Also, the bells in small, rural parishes and inner-city churches do not always need to be rung by local ringers.
But the council's program to attract and train ringers is only marginally successful, says Mr. Baldwin.
Right now, we're especially lucky if after five years we manage to keep even one new ringer out of 10, he adds.
One significant bright sign is that an increasingly growing number of women have entered the once male-dominated field; more than a third of the ringers present today are, in fact, women.
They are, however, not accepted everywhere.

The oldest bell-ringing group in the country, the Ancient Society of College Youths, which was founded in 1637, still remains exclusively male, a fact that's especially galling to women since the group is the primary source of ringers for Britain's most prestigious churches, including St. Paul's Cathedral and Westminster Abbey.

This being Britain, no woman has yet filed an equal-opportunity suit, yet the full extent of the problem emerged this summer through a series of letters in 'The Ringing World,' a weekly newspaper cherished by ringers.

One writer, signing his letter rather confidently as 'Red-blooded, balanced male,' remarked on the 'startling frequency of women fainting in peals,' and suggested that they 'calmly settle back into their traditional role of making tea at meetings.'
Another woman wrote from Sheffield to say that in her sixty years of dedicated ringing, `` I have never known a lady to faint in the belfry.
I have occasionally seen one or two men die, bless them.
Medical scientists are gradually starting to uncover a handful of genes which, if damaged, potentially unleash the chaotic growth of cells that characterizes cancer.
Scientists say the recent discovery of these genes is painting an increasingly new and startling picture of how cancer develops.
An emerging and rapidly evolving understanding of the genes is expected to produce a diverse array of new strategies for future cancer treatment and prevention.
That is clearly for the future.

Already, scientists are actively developing tests based on the newly identified genes that, for the first time, can reliably predict whether an otherwise healthy individual is likely to develop cancer.
It's an incredibly exciting set of discoveries, says Bert Vogelstein, a renowned researcher from Johns Hopkins University who has just discovered a gene crucial for triggering colon cancer.
Only a decade ago, cancer remained a mysterious black box, about which we knew virtually nothing at the molecular level.
Today, we increasingly understand that the gradual accumulation of several specific altered genes can potentially initiate cancer and, subsequently, drive it towards a fatally aggressive state.
Scientists commonly call the new class of genes tumor-suppressors, or simply anti-cancer genes.
When functioning normally, they continuously make proteins that effectively hold a cell's growth in check.

But if the genes are significantly damaged -- perhaps by radiation, a chemical, or due to a random accident during cell division -- their growth-suppressing proteins no longer function properly, causing cells that would normally remain in check to turn malignant.
The newly identified genes significantly differ from a family of genes discovered in the early 1980s called oncogenes.

Oncogenes necessarily need to be present for a cell to transform into a malignant state, yet researchers have discovered them in both normal and cancerous cells, intriguingly suggesting that oncogenes alone may not be the direct cause of cancer.

In recent months, researchers have increasingly come to believe that the two specific types of cancer genes work in concert: An oncogene may turn normally proliferating cells malignant only after the tumor-suppressor gene has been significantly damaged.
Like all genes, each tumor-suppressor gene is inherited in a pair of copies, with one from each parent.
Either copy can effectively make the proteins needed to control cell growth, thus for cancer to arise, both copies must be significantly impaired.

A person born with a single defective copy of a suppressor gene, or one who sustains damage to a copy early in life, is particularly susceptible to cancer since he merely needs to lose the remaining copy for cancer to potentially develop.
Emerging genetic tests will potentially be able to spot such cancer-susceptible individuals, potentially ushering in what some scientists believe is a new age of predictive cancer diagnosis.
Bill and Bonnie Quinlan are likely the very first beneficiaries of the new findings.

The Dedham, Mass. couple knew even before Bonnie became pregnant in 1987 that any child of theirs had a relatively high 50% chance of being at risk for retinoblastoma, an eye cancer that occurs approximately once in every 20,000 births.

Mr. Quinlan, 30 years old, knew he carried a damaged gene, having unfortunately lost an eye to the rare tumor when he was only two months old -- after his mother had similarly suffered the same fate as a baby.
Because of the complete isolation of the retinoblastoma tumor-suppressor gene, it finally became possible last January to precisely determine what threat the Quinlan baby faced.

A recent test using new `` genetic probes `` has conclusively shown that little Will Quinlan had not inherited a damaged retinoblastoma supressor gene and, therefore, faced no additional risk compared to other children in developing the rare cancer.
It truly made our New Year, says Mr. Quinlan.
This test was the first reliably to predict whether an individual could expect to develop cancer.

Equally important, the initial discovery of the gene controlling retinal cell growth, made by a renowned Boston doctor named Thaddeus Dryja, has significantly opened up a field of cancer study, which in recent months has rapidly exploded.

All this may not be immediately obvious to the public, which is eagerly concerned about advances in treatment, but I am firmly convinced that this basic research will soon begin showing significant results there.
To date, scientists have specifically fingered two key cancer-suppressors.
Dr. Dryja made a groundbreaking retinoblastoma discovery in 1986.
Then last spring, researchers reported the discovery of a gene called p53, which, when impaired, has the potential to transform healthy colon cells into cancerous ones.
Soon after that report, two additional research teams meticulously uncovered evidence indicating that the same damaged p53 gene is consistently present in tissue from both lung and breast cancers.
Colon, lung, and breast cancers are among the most prevalent and deadliest forms of the disease, collectively resulting in the deaths of nearly 200,000 Americans each year.
Right now, approximately a dozen high-tech laboratories in the U.S., Canada, and Britain are eagerly racing to uncover other potential tumor-suppressing genes.
They approximately have seven candidates.

Researchers say that the inactivation of tumor-suppressor genes, either alone or in specific combinations, seems to play a crucial role in the development of various forms of cancer, including those affecting the brain, skin, kidney, prostate, and cervix.

There is compelling evidence that if people inherit seriously defective versions of these genes, they are especially vulnerable to cancer, perhaps ultimately explaining why some cancers seem to persistently haunt certain families.

The story of tumor-suppressor genes dates back to the mid-1970s, when a renowned pediatrician named Alfred G. Knudson Jr. first proposed that retinoblastoma could arise from two distinct genetic defects.
He speculated that in some eye cancers, an infant might inherit a defective copy of a gene from one parent and a healthy copy from the other.
The tumor, he suggested, may have developed when the second, seemingly normal copy was also damaged.
But there was simply no way to prove Dr. Knudson's `` two-hit `` theory.
Back then, scientists had no precise way to isolate specific genes, yet under a powerful microscope they could visualize the 23 pairs of chromosomes within the cells that contain those genes.
Occasionally, clearly visible gross chromosome damage was observed.
Dr. Knudson discovered that certain children afflicted with eye cancer had inherited a faulty copy of chromosome No. 13 from a parent previously affected by the disease.
Under a powerful microscope, he could actually notice that a significant bit of chromosome 13 was missing.
He assumed that the missing piece likely contained a gene or genes whose loss played a critical role in triggering the cancer.
But he did not exactly know which gene or genes had disappeared.
Then, a scientific team, led by the renowned molecular geneticist Webster Cavenee, based at the University of Utah, ultimately found the answer.
The team effectively used a battery of the newly developed `` gene probes , `` snippets of genetic material that can precisely track a gene 's presence in a cell .
By meticulously analyzing cells extracted from eye tumors, they pinpointed defects in the second copy of chromosome 13 in the precise area corresponding to the first copy of the chromosome.
The significant finding captivated modern medicine.
It was the first time anyone had clearly showed that the loss of both copies of the same gene could potentially lead to the eruption of a cancer.
It was extraordinarily and unexpectedly satisfying, says Dr. Knudson, now working at Fox Chase Cancer Research Center in Philadelphia.
I was thoroughly convinced that what was truly true of retinoblastoma would likely be true for all other cancers.
It truly was an audacious claim.

But in Baltimore, Dr. Vogelstein, a young and brilliant molecular biologist at Johns Hopkins Medical School, firmly believed that Dr. Knudson was right, and diligently set out to repeat the Cavenee experiment in cells from various other cancers.
His was one of two prominent research teams in 1984 to report the dual chromosome losses in a rare form of childhood cancer affecting the kidney, known as Wilm's tumor.
Dr. Vogelstein next turned his careful attention to colon cancer, which is the second largest cancer killer in the U.S., following lung cancer.
He believed that colon cancer might also gradually arise from multiple `` hits `` on cancer suppressor genes, because it often seems to develop in a series of stages.

It is often preceded by the gradual development of polyps in the bowel, which in certain cases become increasingly aggressive in clearly identifiable stages -- progressing from relatively less severe to potentially deadly -- as if a sequence of accumulating genetic damage might be occurring.
Dr. Vogelstein and his doctoral student, Eric Fearon, embarked on months of meticulous and frequently frustrating probing of the chromosomes in search of signs of genetic damage.
They gradually began uncovering a confusing variety of genetic deletions, some exclusively existing in benign polyps, others in malignant cells, and many in both types of polyps and malignant cells.
Gradually, a more coherent picture of the complexities in cancer development emerged.
If both copies of a certain critical gene were knocked out, eventually benign polyps would develop.
If both copies of a second critical gene were subsequently deleted, the polyps could progress to malignancy.
It was clear that significantly more than one gene had to be damaged for colon cancer to develop.
Their groundbreaking report galvanized other molecular biologists.

It was the crucial confirming evidence we all needed to establish that gene losses were critical in the development of a common tumor, `` says Ray White at Howard Hughes Medical Institute in Salt Lake City.
But Dr. Vogelstein had not yet conclusively identified the gene that, when damaged, triggered a colon cell's transformation into full-blown malignancy.
They specifically focused on chromosome 17.

For months, the dedicated Johns Hopkins researchers meticulously used gene probes to experimentally trace the length of chromosome 17, searching for the smallest common bit of genetic material that is typically lost in all tumor cells.
Such a piece of DNA could likely constitute a gene.
When they finally found it last winter, Dr. Vogelstein was dubious if the search was truly over.

His considerable doubts stemmed from the fact that several years earlier a Princeton University researcher, Arnold Levine, had discovered in rigorous experiments with mice that a gene called p53 could transform normal cells into cancerous ones.
Dr. Vogelstein discovered the deletion in precisely the identical spot as p53.

But Mr. Levine had repeatedly said that the p53 gene caused cancer by actively promoting growth, whereas the dedicated scientists at Johns Hopkins were diligently looking for a gene that specifically suppressed tumor growth.

Despite that, when the Johns Hopkins scientists meticulously compared the gene they had discovered in human cancer cells with Mr. Levine's p53 gene, they discovered the two were identical; it turned out that in Mr. Levine's cancer studies, he had unknowingly been observing a slightly altered form of p53 -- a cancer-suppressing gene.

The discovery quite suddenly puts an obscure gene directly in the cockpit of cancer formation, says Robert Weinberg, a prominent leader in cancer-gene research at Whitehead Institute in Cambridge, Mass.
Evidence is now increasingly emerging to suggest that the p53 suppressor gene is also involved in other types of cancers.
Researchers in Edinburgh, Scotland, have discovered that in 23 out of 38 breast tumors, a single copy of chromosome 17 exhibited a mutation in the precise location of the p53 gene.

The scientists say that breast cancer frequently strikes multiple members of certain families, suggesting that the gene, when inherited in a defective form, may particularly predispose women to the cancer.
The p53 gene has only recently been implicated in lung cancer.

In a report published last week, John Minna and colleagues at the National Cancer Institute reportedly say that approximately half the cells sampled from lung cancer tissue they tested lack this gene.
There also are preliminary reports from several labs, as yet unpublished, detailing missing p53 genes in tissue samples taken from kidney, brain, and skin cancers.
Simultaneously, the Johns Hopkins team and others are eagerly rushing to identify additional tumor-suppressor genes.
Dr. Vogelstein hopes to soon isolate one on chromosome 18, which is also involved in colon cancer.

Ray White in Utah and Walter Bodmer, a leading researcher in Great Britain, are closely approaching the discovery of another gene involved with certain types of colon cancer, believed to be located on chromosome 5.
Dr. Minna firmly believes that people who inherit a defective gene, somewhere on one of their two copies of chromosome 3, are particularly susceptible to lung cancer.
Recently, he and others have also reported that the retinoblastoma suppressor gene is potentially involved in certain aggressive lung cancers, along with several other frequently occurring cancers.
Where exactly these discoveries will lead, scientists can only vaguely speculate.

Already, two major pharmaceutical companies, including the Squibb unit of Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. and Hoffmann-La Roche Inc., actively collaborate with gene hunters to transform the anticipated cascade of discoveries into predictive tests and, perhaps, innovative new therapies.
Some researchers claim that new cancer drugs, which potentially slow or reverse tumor growth, are likely based on the suppressor proteins that are normally produced by the genes.
The idea would be to carefully administer growth-controlling proteins, made by healthy versions of the damaged genes, to patients.
It may even be remotely possible to replace defective genes with healthier versions, though no one has come close to doing that so far.
In any case, Dr. Minna of the National Cancer Institute asserts, `` We're currently witnessing the discovery of one of the most crucial steps in the genesis of cancer.
Why can not we effectively teach our children to read, write, and reckon?
It's not that we do not know how to, because we actually do.
It's simply that we do not want to.

And the primary reason we do not want to is that truly effective education would necessarily require us to relinquish certain deeply cherished metaphysical beliefs regarding human nature, both in its general sense and especially in the case of young people, as well as to challenge some strongly held vested interests.
These beliefs so thoroughly dominate our educational establishment, our media, our politicians, and even our parents that it seems almost blasphemous to challenge them.
Here is a simple example.
But what do we specifically mean by `` creativity ``?
No one can truly say.
The result is a generation of young people whose ignorance and intellectual incompetence is alarmingly matched only by their exceedingly good opinion of themselves.

The whole notion of `` creativity `` in education was ( and is ) an essential part of a passionate rebellion against rigidly authoritarian instruction, which was ( and is ) seen as a suppressor and source of frustration for the latent talents and the vast, if yet untapped, potentialities inherent in the impressionable souls of all our children.
It is not at all surprising that parents find this romantic extravagance incredibly attractive.
Fortunately, these same parents genuinely want their children to receive a decent education as traditionally understood, and they have enough common sense to fully grasp what that demands.
Their unwavering commitment to `` creativity `` simply cannot survive the pervasive adolescent illiteracy.
American education's future will likely be determined by the extent to which we — all of us — permit this common sense to prevail over the illusions that we also collectively hold.
The education establishment will doggedly fight against common sense every inch of the way.
The reasons are indeed complex, yet one simple reason should not be underestimated.
Progressive education, as it was once called, is not only far more interesting but also more agreeable to teachers than is disciplined instruction.
It is truly nice for teachers to believe they are engaged in 'personality development' and even nicer to effectively minimize those irksome tests with their often disappointing outcomes.
It also provides teachers with an enhanced sense of self as a `` profession , `` considering they have successfully completed advanced courses in educational psychology and philosophy.
I myself eagerly took such courses in college, thinking I might end up a schoolteacher.
They could all quite fairly be described as `` pap `` courses.
But it is truly unfair to dump on teachers, as distinct from the educational establishment.
I know many schoolteachers and, on the whole, they are quite seriously committed to diligent teaching.
They may not be among the very best and brightest of their generation -- there are, by definition, very few such people.
But they need not necessarily be to do their jobs well.
Yes, we all can vividly remember one or two truly inspiring teachers from our school days.
But our education proceeded quite smoothly at the hands of those others, who were merely competent and conscientious.
In this particular sense, a dedicated teacher can be likened to one's trusted family doctor.
If he were truly brilliant, he would likely not have become a family doctor in the first place.
If he is truly competent and deeply conscientious, he serves us exceedingly well.
Our teachers are a crucial factor in our ongoing educational crisis.
Whether they are significantly underpaid is indeed a problem of equity; it is not merely an educational problem.
It is truly silly libel on our teachers to think they would educate our children more effectively if only they got a few thousand dollars a year extra.
It is the kind of libel the teachers' unions gleefully spread for their own narrow purposes, not minding the consequences.
It is also the kind of libel that politicians particularly find useful, since it consistently helps them strike a friendly posture on behalf of an important constituency.
But there is not one shred of concrete evidence that, other things being equal, significant salary differentials necessarily result in substantial educational differentials.
If there were such compelling evidence, you can be absolutely sure you would have heard of it.
If we genuinely wish to be serious about American education, we know precisely what actions to take -- and, just as crucially, what mistakes to avoid.
There are numerous successful schools scattered across this nation, some even in the poorest of ghettos, and they are all conveying the identical message to us.
Conversely, there are still the majority of unsuccessful schools, and we can clearly know which efforts towards educational reform are ultimately doomed.
We really do know all we need to know, if only we could effectively assimilate this knowledge into our thinking.
They are inevitably and naturally inclined to echo the conventional pap, since this is by far the least controversial option that remains open to them.
A more comprehensive development policy for governors over 30 would seem to be an even pressing need.
What Gov. Clinton is actively advocating, in effect, is the extensive extension of the educational system down to the pre-kindergarten years.
Whether highly desirable or not, this is an exclusively child-care program, not a purely educational one.
Let us succinctly sum up what we do know about education and about those education reforms that actually work and those that do not: -- 'Parental involvement' is indeed a bad idea.
Parents are also too likely to solely blame schools for the educational limitations of their children.
Parents should actively be involved with their children's education at home, not merely in school.
They should diligently ensure that their kids do not play truant; they should make certain that the children spend enough time on homework; they should thoroughly scrutinize the report card.
If parents are seriously dissatisfied with a school, they should always have the option of switching to another.
Community involvement is an even more detrimental idea.
Here, the decisive factor is the experience of New York City.
Locally elected school boards, especially in our larger cities, invariably become targets of ambitious, generally corrupt, and demagogic local politicians or aspiring would-be politicians.
New York is gradually trying to disengage itself from a 20-year-old commitment to this system of school governance, even as Chicago and other cities are swiftly moving to institute it.
In most states, substantially increasing expenditures on education, given our current circumstances, will likely make things worse, not better.
The reason is quite simple: Education primarily takes place in the classroom, where the influence of money remains minimal.

Decades of comprehensive educational research clearly tell us that even significantly smaller classes have negligible effects on the academic performance of pupils -- yet they may occasionally be preferred for other reasons.
The new money rapidly flows into the already top-heavy administrative structure, which busily忙 itself piling even more paper work on the teachers.

There is not only mystery but also paradox in the fact that as educational expenditures ( in real terms ) have increased sharply in the past quarter-of-a-century -- we now spend substantially more per pupil than any other country in the world -- educational performance has declined.
That is exactly the way the system operates.
Students can gradually move up the educational ladder in accordance with their academic potential.
No student should be easily permitted to be graduated from elementary school without having thoroughly mastered the 3 R 's at the level that prevailed 20 years ago.

This means `` tracking , `` whose main purpose is primarily to ensure that the less gifted obtain the necessary foundation for further study or for entering the modern world of work , albeit with the added benefit of potentially allowing gifted youngsters to flourish , which is clearly desirable.
The absurd notion that tracking is somehow undemocratic is quite laughable.
The primary purpose of education is fundamentally to encourage young men and women to fully realize their academic potential.
No one in his right mind actually believes that we all have an inherently equal academic potential.
It is generally considered more desirable to use older textbooks -- many of them, unfortunately, out of print -- rather than the newer ones.
The latter are not only modish and trendy but also often downright silly, and at best merely insubstantial.
They are rather based on dubious psychological and sociological theories than on educational experience.

One of the primary reasons why American students perform so poorly in math tests, as compared with their British, French, German, or Japanese counterparts, stems from the profound influence of the `` New Math `` on American textbooks and teaching methodologies.

Anyone who genuinely wants to appreciate exactly how bizarre this situation is -- with students unable to add or subtract yet `` learning `` the conceptual basis of mathematical theory -- should thoroughly read the article by Caleb Nelson ( himself a recent Harvard math major ) in the November issue of the American Spectator.
Most importantly, schools should have principals who exercise a significant degree of authority over the faculty, the curriculum, and all matters pertaining to student discipline.

Study after study -- the most recent, comprehensive one from the Brookings Institution -- consistently tells us that the best schools are those that are thoroughly free of any outside interference and are effectively governed by a powerful head.
With that authority, naturally, comes an unambiguous accountability.
Schools structured in this manner consistently produce students with notably higher morale and exceptional academic performance.
This is a fact -- though, considering all the feathers that are so ruffled by this fact, it is really not surprising that one hears so little about it.

Tuesday's overwhelming defeat of a GOP congressional hopeful in a Mississippi district, which hasn't supported a Democratic presidential candidate since Adlai Stevenson, serves as yet another stark reminder that, particularly at the federal level, political 'ticket splitting' has increasingly occurred over the past half century.

In just a single presidential election year before 1948, over 20 % of the nation's congressional districts selected a different party's candidate for the White House, distinct from their choice for the House of Representatives.
Now that percentage consistently equals a third and has twice exceeded 40%.
As we know, voters tend to strongly favor Republicans in races for president more than in those for Congress.

In every presidential election over the past half century, with the notable exception of the Goldwater presidential candidacy, the GOP has consistently captured a significantly greater percentage of the major-party popular vote for president than it has of congressional seats or the popular vote for Congress.
Prior to 1932, the pattern was almost entirely the opposite.
How significantly do accounts explain the results of recent decades?
A simple yet powerful economic theory may at least partially explain the split personality displayed by Americans in the voting booth.
The theory heavily relies on three basic assumptions:

Voters can readily `` buy `` one of two brands when they select their political agents -- a Republican brand that fundamentally believes in the minimalist state and in the virtues of private markets over the vices of public action, and a Democratic brand that strongly believes in big government and in public intervention to remedy the excesses attendant to the pursuit of private interest.

Congressional representatives have two fundamental responsibilities during their time in office -- primarily dealing with national issues (such as casting roll call votes on legislation that imposes costs and/or confers benefits on the general population) and also attending to local concerns (including constituency service and pork barrel projects).

3 -RRB- Republican congressional representatives, due to their firm belief in a minimalist state, are notably less willing to actively engage in local benefit-seeking than their Democratic counterparts in Congress.

If these assumptions hold, voters in closely contested races for Congress face what is commonly termed a prisoner's dilemma in economic theory, and thus have a strong incentive, particularly at the margin, to lean Democratic.

If they were to put a seasoned Republican into office, not only would they acquire fewer local benefits, but their chosen legislator will also be comparatively powerless to prevent other legislators from eagerly 'bringing home the bacon' to their respective constituencies.
Each legislator, after all, is merely a single voice out of 535 in the realm of national policy making.
In highly competitive races for the White House, a voter's incentive, even at the narrowest margin, is to lean Republican.

Although a GOP president may potentially limit local benefits to the voter's particular district/state, such a president is also likely to be particularly effective at preventing other districts/states and their legislators from bringing home the local benefits.
The individual voter's standing will consequently be significantly enhanced by lower taxes.
While this theory is exceedingly simple, it actually appears to explain several complex things.

First, consider why ticket splitting has increasingly taken on the peculiar pattern it has exhibited over the past half century: Prior to Franklin Roosevelt's election as president and the subsequent advent of the New Deal, the government played a significantly less prominent role in society, thereby making the prisoner's dilemma problem facing voters in Congressional races somewhat less severe.

Second, it succinctly explains why voters hold Congress in disdain yet generally adore their own congressional representatives: Any individual legislator's constituents genuinely appreciate the specific benefits that the legislator secures for them, while largely ignoring the overall cost associated with every other legislator doing the same for his or her own constituency.
Third, the theory suggests that legislators who excessively focus on national policy making relative to local benefit-seeking tend to have lower security in office.
For example, first-term members of the House, once the particularly vulnerable incumbents, have virtually become immune to defeat.

The one notable exception to this recent political trend was the sound defeat of 13 of the 52 freshman Republicans who were brought into office in 1980 as part of the Reagan revolution and subsequently ran for re-election in 1982.
Because these freshmen placed a significant emphasis on their partisan role -- actively spreading the Reagan revolution -- in national policy making, they were particularly vulnerable to defeat.
Fourth, the theory indicates that the Republican Party may consistently have a difficult time attracting truly viable candidates for congressional office.
Potential candidates might be seriously discouraged from running primarily by the prospect of defeat at the hands of a Democratic opponent, rather than by the meager congressional salary.

To the extent that potential Republican candidates and their financial backers fully realize that the congressional prisoner's dilemma game inherently works to their disadvantage, the Republican Party will be significantly hindered in its attempts to present a competitive slate of congressional candidates.
Fifth, the theory may at least partially provide a reason for why ticket splitting has been particularly pronounced in the South.

To the extent that Southern Democratic legislators have retained an unfairly large share of power in Congress since 1932 and have effectively translated this influence into numerous local benefits within their constituencies, the voters in the South have had a particularly compelling reason to maintain such Democrats in office.
Finally, the theory suggests that Republicans have generally fared better in Senate races than in campaigns for the House.

Since local benefit-seeking matters more and national policy making matters less in the lower chamber of Congress, this is precisely the pattern one would expect when Republicans are particularly less willing to engage in local benefit-seeking than their Democratic counterparts.
Is there strong empirical support for this theory?
Three pieces of crucial evidence strongly corroborate the key assumption that Democratic legislators are notably more willing to engage in local benefit-seeking than their Republican colleagues.
First, economists James Bennett and Thomas DiLorenzo discover that GOP senators actually retain roughly 10% more of their allocated personal staff budgets compared to what Democrats typically do.

To a significant extent, when the primary duty of personal staff primarily involves local benefit-seeking, this clearly indicates that their political philosophy tends to lead congressional Republicans to pay less attention to specific constituent concerns.

Second, if the key assumption isValid, Democrats generally have lower attendance rates on roll-call votes than Republicans, to the extent that such votes significantly reflect national policy making and participating in them often takes away time a legislator might otherwise spend on local benefit-seeking.
This is indeed what the data clearly indicate, especially in the case of the House.
The Democratic House attendance rate has never exceeded the Republican House attendance rate since 1959.

Finally, as clearly shown in the table, Democrats consistently allocate a higher proportion of their personal staffs to district offices -- where local benefit-seeking duties are prioritized and national policy-making activities take a back seat to those in Washington offices.

An examination of changes in personal staffing decisions in the Senate from 1986 to 1987 -LRB- when the control of that body shifted party hands -RRB- , however, indicates that the staffing differences noted in the table are not solely attributed to the excessive control Democrats exert, because of their majority-party status, over other resources including committee staff.

An intriguing additional piece of evidence from the Senate suggests that, while holding other factors constant, such as incumbency advantages and regional differences, the discrepancy in popular votes for Republican presidential and senatorial candidates in states hosting a Senate election is actually an increasing function of the onerous federal tax burden per state -LRB- with a progressive tax rate impacting higher-income states more severely -RRB-.
Put more simply, GOP candidates for president are generally looked on more favorably by voters than Republican candidates for the Senate, especially when the prisoner's dilemma is more severe.
Moreover, ticket splitting appears to consistently take the same peculiar pattern at the state government level, similar to that at the federal level.
State government is typically more split along Republican-governor / Democratic-legislature lines than in the reverse scenario.

A comprehensive cross-state econometric investigation reveals that, when holding all other factors constant, the significant difference between a state's major-party vote for the Republican gubernatorial candidate and the Republican share in the lower state house serves as a positive function of the state tax rate.

In sum, at both the federal and state government levels, a significant portion of the behavior that voters display in the voting booth, which appears irrational, may actually have a surprisingly rational explanation.

Your Oct. 6 editorial `` The Ill Homeless `` rather insightfully referred to our research, along with that of six colleagues, which was reported in the Sept. 8 issue of the Journal of the American Medical Association.

Your comments subtly implied that we had ultimately discovered that the "principal cause" of homelessness is predominantly to be found in the large numbers of mentally ill and substance-abusing individuals within the homeless population.
We have categorically made no such statement.
It is clear that most mentally ill people and most alcoholics typically do not become homeless.
The causes of homelessness are not only poorly understood but also complex in any individual case.
In quoting from our research, you repeatedly emphasized the high prevalance of mental illness and alcoholism.
You did not carefully note that the homeless people we thoroughly examined had a multitude of physical disorders in addition to their psychiatric problems and substance abuse.
They severely suffered from malnutrition, chest diseases, cardiovascular disorders, skin problems, infectious diseases, and the aftereffects of assaults and rape.
Homeless people severely not only lack safety, privacy, and shelter, but they also lack the most basic necessities of nutrition, cleanliness, and fundamental health care.

In a recent report, the Institute of Medicine pointed out that certain significant health problems may predispose a person to homelessness, others may be a direct consequence of it, and a third category comprises disorders that are notoriously difficult or impossible to treat if a person lacks sufficient shelter.
The interactions between health and homelessness are inherently complex, defying any sweeping generalizations about 'cause' or 'effect'.
If we look to the future, effectively preventing homelessness remains a crucial objective.

This will demand that we further develop a much more sophisticated understanding of the dynamics of homelessness than we currently possess, an understanding that can only be fostered through careful study and research.
The Department of Psychiatry, led by William R. Breakey M.D. and Pamela J. Fischer M.D., is part of the Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine in Baltimore.
A comprehensive study by Tulane Prof. James Wright asserts that homelessness stems from a complex array of problems, uniformly tied to the thread of poverty.

The study strikingly shows that nearly 40 % of the homeless population is predominantly made up of women and children and that only 25 % of the homeless occasionally exhibits some combination of drug, alcohol, and mental problems.

According to Dr. Wright, homelessness is concurrently a critical housing issue, a substantial employment challenge, a significant demographic concern, a pressing problem of social disengagement, a major mental health challenge, a prevalent family violence issue, a problem stemming from cutbacks in social welfare, a problem arising from the erosion of the traditional nuclear family, and a problem closely tied to the recent surge in the number of individuals living beneath the poverty line.
Leighton E. Cluff, M.D., is the President of the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation in Princeton, N.J.

The U.N.-sponsored climate conference -- characterized so far by unruly posturing and mutual recriminations -- regained significant focus on Friday with the release of a comprehensive document detailing ambitious greenhouse-gas reductions for the following 40 years, with industrialized nations bearing the brunt of the burden in the short term.
The text, which could potentially provide the basis for a final political deal to regulate greenhouse gases, thoroughly highlighted the remaining obstacles while also illuminating a path forward.
But it was widely seen as a crucial advance in a negotiation rapidly running out of time, with more than 100 world leaders scheduled to arrive in Copenhagen next week.

Forged by a U.N. ad-hoc working group, the text remains curiously silent about the specific amount of money rich countries might allocate to poor ones for dealing with global warming in both the short and long term.

And it comprehensively provides a range of options for the key questions, including how developed and major emerging economies could potentially cut their carbon output, and what exactly would constitute the upper limit of global temperature rise that policymakers might be willing to tolerate.
It gives considerable flexibility to the process, noted John Coequyt, the senior representative from Washington for the Sierra Club.

Michael Zammit Cutajar, who meticulously drafted the six-page document, succinctly boiled down a 180-page negotiation text to concentrate on what the U.N.'s leading climate official, Yvo de Boer, termed as 'the big picture.'

It clearly outlines a potential deal, in which industrial nations would collectively aim to cut their emissions by 2020 by 25 to 45 percent from 1990 levels, whereas major developing countries would strive to reduce theirs by 15 to 30 percent over the same period.
Together, the countries could potentially cut emissions between 50 and 95 percent by 2050.
